chapter.title: Project Folder
chapter.para: An OmegaT project consists of a set of folders and files that contain the resources used for translating.
A project is a folder containing, at a minimum, the following files and folder:

listitem.para: This is the project folder that always contains , the project translation memory, and , the statistics data file for the project.
Other files will be added over the course of a translation project.

This file contains the properties of the project and also acts as an address book that specifies where project resources are located. By default, a newly created project will contain all the required resources within its folder, and those resources are assigned the default names below.
: the folder that contains the source files
: the folder where the target files are created
: the folder that contains the glossaries
: the project writable glossary
: the folder that contains the reference translation memories
: the folder that contains the dictionaries
The information contained in omegat.project also includes the source and target languages, their respective tokenizers, the type of segmentation used, etc.

chapter.para: You can assign locations other than the default ones to the various resources either when you create the project, or later on.

For example, you can
instruct OmegaT to create the translated files in a shared folder outside the project folder, in a location easily accessible to your reviewer, or
instruct OmegaT to use a glossary folder from a separate but related project, or
instruct OmegaT to use a reference translation memory folder that you have set up for related projects,
and so on.
You can access the project folder and its folders with the command in the menu.
Creating a project gives it a core hierarchy, but its final structure is not fixed. You can always remove or add files and folders to the project.

note.para: You can also create OmegaT projects either manually or with scripts by copying a set of prewritten files to a new folder:

listitem.para: Any given folder that contains a valid omegat.project file will be recognized by OmegaT as being a translation project.

If the folder is an empty repository and the omegat.project file contains remote repository information, the project will be recognized by OmegaT as being a team project: ... <external_command></external_command> <repositories> <repository type="git" url="https://URL/OF/THE/REMOTE/PROJECT/REPOSITORY"> <mapping local="/" repository="/"/> </repository> </repositories> </project> See for details.

section.title: source
section.para: The source folder contains the files to translate.
The contents of the files in a format that OmegaT supports will be displayed in the pane. See Preferences – for details.
You can freely add or remove files from that folder at any time. You can also structure the source folder in any form you like.
If your translation project involves a number of folders and you feel like working on one folder at a time, change the as you wish.

section.title: target
section.para: This folder is initially empty. It is populated every time you use or . The files in the folder, whether fully translated or not, are then generated here, using the same hierarchy as in the source contents.
The files created here will reflect the current state of the translation. Untranslated segments will remain in the source language.

section.title: tm
section.para: This folder can contain any number of bilingual reference documents (TMX files, but also any file in a bilingual format supported by OmegaT).
To remind you that a match was inserted by OmegaT and not by you, set a prefix in Preferences – . OmegaT will add that prefix to the inserted match.

The contents of the translation memories present suggestions for the text to translate. Any text with a translation in those files will show up in the Fuzzy Matches pane, if it is sufficiently similar to the text in the current segment.
TMX files are read in the order of their names, and the segments within a file are read sequentially.

note.para: TMX files compressed in the gzip format can also be read by OmegaT.

listitem.para: This folder is made for reliable references files that can automatically fill exactly matching and not yet translated segments.

Translations from TMX files placed in this folder are automatically inserted in matching segments without the automatic prefix, making it unnecessary to confirm these segments. Translations coming from this folder are considered to be as reliable as the current project memory.

note.para: Only the tm/auto folder is automatically generated at project creation. You must manually create and fill any other tm folder that you want to use.

listitem.para: Put the applicable memories in the tm/auto folder.
Open the project. You will see that segments identical to source segments in those memories are already filled in. They will be highlighted in orange if you have checked the option in the menu.
Make a minor change anywhere in the project and save it. This will add the translations loaded from the tm/auto folder to the main project_save.tmx file.

warning.para: If you remove a TMX file from tm/auto before Step 3, none of its automatically inserted translations will be kept.

listitem.para: This folder is made for reliable references files that will automatically overwrite or fill exactly matching segments.

Translations from TMX files placed in this folder are automatically inserted in matching segments without the automatic prefix, making it unnecessary to confirm these segments. Translations coming from this folder are considered to be more reliable than the current project memory.

If you have no doubt that a given TMX contains more accurate translations than the current project_save.tmx file, put that TMX in the tm/enforce folder to overwrite the existing translations unconditionally.
Put the applicable memories in the tm/enforce folder.
Open the project. You will see that segments identical to source segments in those memories are already filled in.
Make a minor change anywhere in the project and save. This updates the project_save.tmx file.

Make a decision about the immutability of the enforced segments:
If they don't need to remain immutable to further changes, remove the TMX from tm/enforce.
If they do need to remain immutable to further changes, leave the TMX in tm/enforce. Any modification to the segments that come from these memories will not be taken into account.

warning.para: If you remove a TMX file from tm/enforce before Step 3, none of the enforced translations will be kept.

listitem.para: The background of the active segment changes to red when a match is inserted from a TMX contained in the mt folder. The background is restored to normal when you leave the segment or when you modify the segment.

It can be useful to distinguish between high-quality translation memories and other memories that, due to the subject matter, client, revision status, or other factors,are less reliable. The score of matches from translation memories in folders named penalty-xxx (where xxx is a number between 0 and 100), is decreased by an amount corresponding to the value in the name of the folder. For example, a 100% match in a TMX, stored in a folder called penalty-30 becomes a 70% match. The penalty applies to all three match percentages. Scores of 75, 80 and 90 for a match are lowered to 45, 50 and 60.

OmegaT displays fuzzy matches in the pane. Such matches are by default limited to the source and target languages defined in , but you can also add matches in languages that are not the target language. See for details.
With OmegaT, you can display a third language right under the source segment to use as a third language reference. See for details.

note.para: You can combine folders to create new functions. For example, a 10% penalty folder within the machine translation folder: tm/mt/penalty-010 would never generate 100% matches that could otherwise be automatically inserted by OmegaT, and would always set a red background to the match whenever it is inserted.

section.title: dictionary
section.para: This folder is initially empty, and is used to store any dictionaries you add to the project.
Dictionary terms that match parts of the segment are displayed in the pane. See Preferences – for details.
OmegaT supports dictionaries in the StarDict or in the Lingvo DSL format. You can find some dictionaries on the OmegaT Wiki. To install the dictionaries:

listitem.para: download the file - it should be a tarball archive (extension tar.bz or tar.bz2),
extract its contents into this folder. There should be three files per dictionary, with extensions dz, idx and ifo.

section.para: If you want to remove words from potential dictionary matches, add an ignore.txt encoded in UTF-8 to the folder. The file must have one word per line. All the words contained in that list will be ignored by OmegaT when matching segment terms in the installed dictionaries.

section.title: glossary
section.para: This folder is initially empty. It is used to store the default writable glossary and any other glossaries you use in the project. See for details.

listitem.para: This is the project writeable glossary. It is created the first time you use .
You can access it with , open it in a text editor, modify it with a text editor. As soon as you have saved your modifications, they will be taken into account by OmegaT.

section.title: omegat
section.para: The omegat folder contains, at a minimum, the and files. It may also include several other files.

listitem.para: This is the most important file in the project. An empty file is automatically generated when you create a new project, and is gradually filled with the translations of the text in files located in the folder.
It constitutes the working translation memory of the project.
OmegaT regularly backs-up that file. See for details.

This file is a backup of project_save.tmx and is automatically recreated everytime project_save.tmx has been modified: either after using , or as a regular backup every 3 minutes by default. See for details.
Every time a project is loaded, OmegaT creates a backup of project_save.tmx with the name project_save.tmx.[time stamp].bak. OmegaT keeps up to 10 of those files.
This is the statistics file for the whole project. It is updated each time the project is reloaded.
You can also update it with the command in the menu.
This file contains the latest project match statistics, which are generated by the command in the menu.
This file contains the latest project match statistics by file, which are generated by the command in the menu.

These files are created and used by the spellchecker. You can add terms by right-clicking on a word marked as incorrect and selecting Ignore All (for words to skip during spellchecking), or Add to Dictionary (for words to accept as correct), respectively, from the .

If you already have a collection of words you want the spellchecker to ignore or accept, simply save them in text files with the corresponding names, and copy the files to the folder of your current project.
This file contains the project-specific segmentation rules.
This file contains the project-specific file filters.
This file contains the project-specific GUI settings.
This file contains the project-specific external searches.
This file is created if you manually change the order of the files in the window.
This file keeps a record of the last segment you visited, including its number, its source contents, the file name and the date, so that you can come back to it when you reload/relaunch the project.

section.title: omegat.project
section.para: This file contains the project parameters defined in the .

section.title: .repositories
section.para: In a team project, this folder contains a versioned copy of the project tree structure linked directly to the remote server.

You can make changes to the remote files (such as deleting or replacing them) by making your changes in this folder and using a Git or SVN client to synchronize them with the remote server. See for details.
In some operating systems, this folder is hidden by default. Turn on the option to show hidden files in your system to make it visible.
